moves.6... Nf6 7. h3 Be7 8. g4: The key move. Best for black is to develop and castle queenside.
moves.10. h4 Nxe5 11. dxe5 Ne4 12. Bg3: Good for black is to exchange. But he has another good idea.
moves.12... g5: If h5, everything is blocked on the kingside.
moves.13... Nxg3 14. fxg3 gxh4: I thought here about Qc2, and probably it is better. Anyway, I decided to set a little trap.
moves.15. Qf3: He thinks that I intend to retake g3 with the queen, overlooking...
moves.15... hxg3 16. Rxh6 Bg5: Well calculated by black. I thought about the sac Rh8+, KxR, Qh1+, Kg7, Bd3, but after Rh8 I had nothing, so...
moves.17. Rh5: Best for black is BxN+, KxN, d4, exploiting white's king unprotected position. I could survive it, but it was not easy to play.
moves.17... Kg7: Ok, intending to cover the h column with Rh8.
moves.18. O-O-O: Necessary? I was worried about d4.
moves.18... Kg6: Now, this is a wasted tempo. Better was Rh8.
moves.19. Qxg3 f6: Nf3 was ok, I guess. But the check was too nice to miss.
moves.20. Bd3+ Kg7: f5 was not playable because after gxf5, the bishop is pinned and attacked.
moves.22... f5 23. Rh8+ Kf7 24. Qh5+: Not Qh7, Ke8 (even if RxR+, KxR, Qh8+ leads to more or less the same result: the Bg4 is lost. This is why BxN+ was advidable for black, a move before.
moves.24... Kg7: A loses inmediately. But after Ke7, QxB+, the game was won all the same.
